body: Thanks for the review @fhueske. I will merge this...

Thanks very much.

The initial PR should have one commit. Following changes should be put as commits on top of the initial commit. But you are right, we should update the contribution guidelines to make this more clear.

Do we know the underlying reason that is causing YARN to fail now? None of the config values seem to have changed in a long time.
nvm, found the reference to FLINK-5904 in the JIRA.
@zjureel my main concern is the need of our own timeout when Kafka has the `max.block.ms` configuration. This seems to be the max timeout you're talking about?
@zentol do you agree to merge this now. Its the last thing I would like to get into RC1.

@rmetzger what is happening in `create_release_files.sh:deploy_to_maven`? Are we overwriting the 2.11 quickstart jars with 2.10 jars? Are we still looking to publish against Scala 2.10 rather than 2.11?
Thanks for the review @zentol. I'll address your comment and then merge the PR once Travis gives green light.
+1 to merge after you've changed it back to 1024.
rebased on master branch

@zentol "The time that the job has not been running in a failing/recovering situation." is confusing. How about this:

The time the job has spent in a failing/recovering situation.

Thanks for the reviewing. @fhueske Move the check logic from `rule` into `Table API validation` phase make sense to me. That is `Table API validation` ensure the `Semantics` and `rule` ensure the `Runtime` can deal with the situation. The PR. is updated. :)

Thanks,
SunJincheng

@alpinegizmo That's better, but still a bit unambiguous. The `downtime` only measures since the last time the job went into a non-running state, whereas the description could mean "Total job downtime since job submission." :/

i will make a number of changes before merging it.

- added a hack to deal with options using `System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir")` as the default value
- replace `>` and `<` in descriptions and default values
- all keys are now tagged as `<h5>` to allow linking
- empty String default values are treated as not having a default value
@zentol can you please take another look? Thanks.
You will have to rebase this PR and adjust the tests. I recently modified the cassandra tests to no longer run any actual jobs and to use a different table for each test.
Apart from the above this looks ok to me.
My understanding is that the snippet should only depend on the Java version of the API (`ROW_NAMED` in flink-core) instead of the one written in Scala that resides in `flink-table`. Correct?
Merged
R: @rmetzger for review, please ðŸ™‚

Honestly, I need more review by myself which can saving the time of other reviewer.
Best,
SunJincheng
Yes, user can config the timeout and retry times to fetch kafka meta beyond the configuration of kafka itself.  @tzulitai
@zjureel then I would suggest to remove the usage of ExecutorService for the timeout. In what other cases would that be required?
Use [https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/3915](url) instead
@tzulitai Could you please review code here when you are free, thanks :)
@zentol Thank you for your reply, I have update the code and add space after `try`

The Java version of the API also depends on the Scala classes of `flink-table`. Everything in `org.apache.flink.table.api` is used in both languages. `org.apache.flink.table.api.scala/java` contain language specific classes.
Also, it seems like 0.8 does support a timestamp-based offset retrieval. See the "finding start offsets for reads" in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/0.8.0+SimpleConsumer+Example.

Any updates on this sink?

Merging this after travis gives me also the green light.
@tzulitai I agree with you and `ExecutorService` is really unnecessary. I will update the code and remove `ExecutorService`

Thanks for turning this around quickly @tillrohrmann We are experiencing this issue with AWS EMR.  Is it possible to patch the current 1.2.0 version available via EMR?

@johnboy14 I can merge this PR also into the `1.2` branch. This means that it will be included in the next bug fix release `1.2.2`. How quickly it will be included in EMR depends a little bit on the AWS/Apache BigTop. We can try to ping them. But if customers complain, then it's much more efficient.

Are you interested in contributing a streaming HBase sink?
Can anyone take a look at this one?

This is not decided yet. Usually we do it depending on the urgency of the fixes and the time since the last bug fix release. Currently, we're working on the `1.3` release which requires most of our time. Thus, I would assume not before mid of next month but this is a community decision.
@sunjincheng121 thanks for this PR. @fhueske what do you think of enabling checkstyle's `includeTestSourceDirectory`?

Sorry, I did not manage to merge this, yet. Will try to take it on after the 1.3 release.
Thanks for the offer to rebase that. I can ping you when I would be getting close to merging this, so that you could rebase it once then (rather than now and potentially again in a few weeks).

Hi, I'm testing one myself with a third party library, http://opentsdb.github.io/asynchbase.
I'm following a simliar approach as cassandra sink. Testing it as we speak.
Thanks
@twalthr, it seems we have reserved the keyword with the case insensitive. For instance, we cannot use "Sum" and "SUM", as "sum" is reserved. Did we intent to filter the keyword like this?
At this time I am looking a workaround. Is there anyway to override the log4j.properties file for each application deployed to EMR?
Perhaps we should enable checkstyle on test sources when upgrading to the strict checkstyle.
@greghogan that would make sense to me. Not sure why we excluded the tests in the first place.
@shaoxuan-wang the function catalog is case insensitive anyway. With this PR we have almost no keywords anymore. So a "sum" could be overwritten by "SUM".
The PR looks good to me. +1 from my side.
+1 to merge
+1 to this from my side. Makes logs in cases of TaskManager easier to search through.
@zentol can you take another look?
I see. Thank you. =)
@tzulitai we are interested in putting this feature in production soon. Do you think whether it is possible for us to get a workaround for 1.3? Thanks.

Hi @fhueske Thanks a lot for your suggestions.I have updated the PR. according the comments.

Best,
SunJincheng
@haohui I can not guarantee this, but I can try revisiting this for a workaround after I've finished with  testing on the current RC1.
Thanks for your fix, i'll check in a day or two.
Hi @ramkrish86 , sorry I don't have bandwidth working on it..
+1 to merge
Any concerns regarding this change @tzulitai @StephanEwen @StefanRRichter ?

No concern, just curious if there is any reason for the 1 additional as magic number. The problem also still exists now for a second element. So is it, in general, unlikely that new elements are added? Or should we add some more additional space, like 10%?
Share the same question as Stefan. Otherwise LGTM.

At least in the Table API / SQL operators, we use a ProcessFunction to add elements to a `List` hold in a `MapState` (as described above) in the `processElement()` method. So the cases that I want to improve just add a single element.

My rational was that this is the most common use case (I might be wrong here) and increasing the capacity by 1 seemed like a small price for an improvement. I would be fine with adding more, but the question is how often are more elements added and how many.

If the only case we currently know of right now is in the Table API with 1 additional element to be added, then I think this is good for now.

I think the improvement should be bounded to specific cases anyway, because the problem will always exist no matter how much extra space we add. For example the `ArrayListSerializer` used for list state could have any arbitrary amounts of elements added.

Yes, there is a tradeoff, and probably the nicest way would be to restore the internal array size as it was when we serialized the original. However, I guess that is too much effort for the effect. Since the sweetspot also depends on the access pattern, I think everything from +1 to some percentage could be justified and as there is no clear "best strategy" I would leave this up to your judgment call.

+1 from me then.
Thank you, I'll merge this then.
Currently trying to fix some throttling issues, reported here https://github.com/OpenTSDB/asynchbase/issues/162

Hi @DmytroShkvyra, I'm sorry for the long time without response on this PR.
We're currently in "testing & bugfix mode" for the 1.3 release and I'll be gone for two weeks in a few days. I'm sorry, but I won't have much time to look at this PR until I return.
The Java7 run failed because my solution uses Java8 features. I guess I have to find another way to fix this issue then.
@zentol Would you mind checking that I got the shading right?

@zjureel For Kafka 0.11, I would expect it to just extend `FlinkKafkaConsumer010`.
As you can see, that is also the case right now for 010; its extending `FlinkKafkaConsumer09` and not the base class.

An alternative I can agree with is implementing the method in the base class (instead of throwing `RuntimeException`), and letting the versions that do not support the method override and throw an exception. Therefore, the other way around as to what you are currently doing.

What do you think?
